newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: IRISH TELECOM LAUNCHES KPN/TELIA ALLIANCE.
newsitem.headline: IRISH TELECOM LAUNCHES KPN/TELIA ALLIANCE.

text.p: State-owned Irish telecommunications company Telecom Eireann on Thursday formally launched its strategic alliance with the Dutch and Swedish telecom companies, KPN and Telia.
"Our strategic alliance with KPN and Telia will enable Telecom to embark on a new era of growth and opportunity," Telecom Eireann chief executive Alfie Kane said in a statement.
New developments for the alliance will include continued and accelerated reductions in prices, better quality service and more advanced and innovative products and services, Kane said.

"I am confident that our new partnership will result in new and lasting benefits for our customers," he said, adding he wanted customers to receive an immediate benefit to mark the link-up with KPN and Telia by halving the weekend charges.
Ireland announced the sale of a stake in Telecom Eireann to the Swedish-Dutch consortium in June 1996 for a sum expected to exceed 500 million punts ($792 million).

The then Irish communications minister Michael Lowry said at the time that KPN/Telia would pay 183 million punts for 20 percent of Telecom Eireann and had the option to buy a further 15 percent for 200 million over the following three years.

KPN and Telia would pay additional amounts according to a profit-share formula, which was expected to take the total amount paid above 500 million punts, Lowry said in the June statement on the sale of the stake.
